user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_get_fdset:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_get_fdset (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
               fd_set *read_fd_set,
               fd_set *write_fd_set,
               fd_set *except_fd_set,
               MHD_socket *max_fd)
{
  return MHD_get_fdset2 (daemon,
                         read_fd_set,
                         write_fd_set,
                         except_fd_set,
                         max_fd,
#ifdef HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE
                         daemon->fdset_size_set_by_app ?
                         ((unsigned int) daemon->fdset_size) :
                         ((unsigned int) _MHD_SYS_DEFAULT_FD_SETSIZE)
#else  /* ! HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE */
                         ((unsigned int) _MHD_SYS_DEFAULT_FD_SETSIZE)
#endif /* ! HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE */
                         );
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
#ifdef HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE
                         daemon->fdset_size_set_by_app ?
                         ((unsigned int) daemon->fdset_size) :
                         ((unsigned int) _MHD_SYS_DEFAULT_FD_SETSIZE)
#else  /* ! HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE */
                         ((unsigned int) _MHD_SYS_DEFAULT_FD_SETSIZE)
#endif /* ! HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE */
explanation: The only location in this function that can produce code that is never compiled or never executed is the preprocessor-controlled block selecting the fdset size. Depending on whether HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE is defined at compile time, one of the branches will be omitted entirely; that can create code that is unreachable in a given build configuration and thus should be reviewed. At runtime the ternary expression (daemon->fdset_size_set_by_app ? ... : ...) uses a non-constant condition, so both arms are potentially reachable at execution time; therefore no other lines in the function present obvious unreachable-code concerns. The rest of the function consists of a single return calling MHD_get_fdset2 with the selected value and has no statements after a return or constant-false condition that would indicate unreachable code.
